{{Multiple issues| {{POV|date=November 2017|talk=Article structure}} {{Primary sources|date=November 2017}} }} {{Use American English|date=September 2017}}
'''Racial color blindness''', also called '''race blindness''', is a term in American [[sociology]] for the disregard of [[Race (classification of human beings)|racial]] characteristics when selecting which individuals will participate in some activity or receive some service. In practice, color-blind operations use no racial data or profiling and make no classifications, categorizations, or distinctions based upon race. An example of this would be a college processing admissions without regard to or knowledge of the racial characteristics of applicants.<ref>{{Cite journal | last =Burdman | first =Pamela | title = Exposing the truth and fiction of racial data | journal = [[University of California, Berkeley|California Magazine]] | pages = 40–46 | url = http://media.wix.com/ugd/ebe046_d0481d3c435d4ba4a20050ce39109744.pdf | publisher = [[University of California, Berkeley|Cal Alumni Association]] | date = August 2003 | accessdate =18 January 2008 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
The goal of 1960s civil-rights legislation in the United States was to remove racial discrimination and so establish a race-blind standard. [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]'s central hope was that people would someday be judged by "the content of their character" rather than "the color of their skins".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=David O. |last2=Sidanius |first2=Jim |last3=Bobo |first3=Lawrence D. | title = Racialized politics: the debate about racism in America |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago, Ill. |date=2000 |isbn=978-0-22-674407-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OJpCt9CsEe0C&pg=PA6 |page=6}}</ref> Whether color-blind policies provide the best means of achieving racial equality remains controversial as many in support of color blindness{{Who|date=November 2017}} typically circumvent acknowledging race to avoid racial feuds and attempt to eliminate the negative past in race relations. Although race is a social construction that was created to uphold a hierarchal social structure, critics to color blindness{{Who|date=November 2017}} say that it is more than that. Race is a “dominant social category that affects how one looks at the world and affects how the world looks at you.”<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jakubowski|first1=Dawn|title=THE RHETORIC OF COLOR-BLINDNESS|journal=Scarborough: National Association of African American Studies|date=2004|pages=1230-1242}}</ref>
==Overview==
Racial color blindness reflects an ideal society in which skin color is insignificant. The ideal was most forcefully articulated in the context of the [[U.S. civil rights movement]] and international [[anti-racist]] movements of the 1950s and 1960s.{{sfnp|Ansell|2013|p=42}} Advocates for color blindness argue that persons should be judged not by their skin color but rather by "the content of their character", in the words of [[Martin Luther King Jr.]]{{sfnp|Ansell|2013|p=42}} Color-blind ideology is based on tenets of non-discrimination, [[due process]] of law, [[equal protection]] under the law, and [[equal opportunities]] regardless of race, ideas which have strongly influenced Western [[liberalism]] in the post-World War II period.{{sfnp|Ansell|2013|pp=42–3}}
Proponents of "color-blind" practices{{Who|date=September 2017}} believe that treating people equally inherently leads to a more equal society or that racism and race privilege no longer exercise the power they once did, rendering policies such as race-based [[affirmative action]] obsolete. As articulated by U.S. Chief Justice [[John Roberts]], "The way to stop discrimination on the basis of race, is to stop discriminating on the basis of race."<ref name='Amy Stuart Wells 33'>{{cite book |last1=Stuart Wells |first1=Amy |title=Both Sides Now: The Story of School Desegregation's Graduates |publisher=University of California Press |year=2009 |page=33 |isbn=978-0-52-025678-1}}</ref>
In ''Social Inequality and Social Stratification in US Society'', Christopher Doob writes that "color-blind racism" represents "whites' assertion that they are living in a world where racial privilege no longer exists, but their behavior supports racialized structures and practices".<ref>{{cite book |last=Doob |first=Christopher B. |title=Social Inequality and Social Stratification in U.S. Society |publisher=Pearson |location=Upper Saddle River, N.J. |date=2013 |isbn=978-0-20-579241-2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u85zCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT445&dq=%22racial+privilege%22}}</ref>
Sociologist [[Eduardo Bonilla-Silva]] has described four "frames" that he says guide color-blind thinking. According to Bonilla-Silva, ''abstract liberalism'' is the most important of these frames and forms the foundation of color-blind ideology.{{sfnp|Bonilla-Silva|2010|pp=26–28}} This involves invoking abstract ideas such as "equal opportunity" and "individual choice" while opposing concrete proposals to reduce inequality. This perspective tends to ignore the under-representation of [[people of color]] in prestigious jobs and schools, along with institutional practices that encourage segregation. ''Naturalization'' is used by whites to explain racial segregation (including [[self-segregation]]) as "natural" and "just the way things are". ''[[Cultural racism]]'' relies on cultural, rather than biological, explanations such as "blacks have too many babies" to account for racial inequality. A fourth frame is ''minimization of racism''.{{sfnp|Bonilla-Silva|2010|pp=28–30}}
==Support==
Professor [[William Julius Wilson]] of Harvard University has argued that "class was becoming more important than race" in determining life prospects within the black community.<ref name="William Julius Wilson">{{cite news| publisher = PBS| title = Interview William Julius Wilson| url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/race/interviews/wilson.html| accessdate = 29 December 2013 | year = 1997}}</ref> Wilson has published several works including ''The Declining Significance of Race'' (1978) and ''The Truly Disadvantaged'' (1987) explaining his views on black poverty and racial inequality. He believes that [[affirmative action]] primarily benefits the most privileged individuals within the black community. This is because strictly race-based programs disregard a candidate's socioeconomic background and therefore fail to help the poorer portion of the black community that actually needs the assistance.<ref name="William Julius Wilson"/> In a society where millions of blacks live in the middle and upper classes and millions of whites live in poverty, race is no longer an accurate indication of privilege. Recognizing someone's social class is more important than recognizing someone's race, indicating that society should be class-conscious, not race-conscious.
Supreme Court Justice [[Clarence Thomas]], the only current black Justice, supports color-blind policies. He believes the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]] forbids consideration of race, such as race-based affirmative action or preferential treatment. He believes that race-oriented programs create "a cult of victimization" and imply blacks require "special treatment in order to succeed".<ref>{{cite news| publisher = CBS| title = Clarence Thomas: The Justice Nobody Knows| url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/09/27/60minutes/main3305443_page5.shtml| accessdate = 30 December 2013 | date =27 September 2007}}</ref><ref>{{caselaw source |case=''Adarand Constructors, Inc. v. Peña'', 515 U.S. 200 (1995) |findlaw=http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?navby=CASE&court=US&vol=515&page=200 |justia=http://supreme.justia.com/us/515/200/case.html |other_source1=LII |other_url1=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct-cgi/get-us-cite?515+200}}</ref>
==Criticism==
In 1997 Leslie G. Carr published ''Color-Blind Racism'' which reviewed the history of racist ideologies in America. He saw "color-blindness" as an ideology that undercuts the legal and political foundation of [[Racial integration|integration]] and affirmative action. Stephanie M. Wildman, in her book ''Privilege Revealed: How Invisible Preference Undermines America'', writes that many Americans who advocate a merit-based, race-free worldview do not acknowledge the systems of privilege which benefit them. For example, many Americans rely on a social and sometimes even financial inheritance from previous generations. She argues that this inheritance is unlikely to be forthcoming if one's ancestors were [[slavery|slaves]], and privileges whiteness, maleness, and [[heterosexuality]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Wildman | first = Stephanie M. | title = Privilege revealed how invisible preference undermines America | publisher = New York University Press | location = New York | edition = 6th | year = 1996 | isbn = 9780814793039 }}</ref>
“There are concerns that majority groups use color-blindness as a means of avoiding the discussion of racism and discrimination<ref>{{cite book|title=Racism Without Racists: Color-blind racism and the persistence of racial inequality in the United States|last=Bonilla-Silva|first=Eduardo|date=2014|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-1-44-222055-3|edition=4th|pages=101–102|ref=harv}}</ref>. Color-blindness can be seen as a way to undermine the hardships of minority groups, as it used to argue that the United States is a meritocracy, in which people that succeed because they work hard not because of their privilege<ref>{{cite journal|author=Gallagher, Charles A.|date=2003|title=Color-Blind Privilege: The Social and Political Functions of Erasing the Color Line in Post Race America|journal=Race, Gender & Class|volume=10|issue=4|pages=22–37|jstor=41675099}}</ref>. Critics of this{{Who|date=November 2017}} are fast to point to statistics that contradicts this notion of meritocracy, for example, the average black or Hispanic household earning more than $75,000 still live in a less affluent, resource-rich neighborhood than a white household that earns less than $40,000<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Logan|first=John R.|date=July 2011|title=Separate and Unequal: The Neighborhood Gap for Blacks, Hispanics, and Asians in Metropolitan America|url=https://s4.ad.brown.edu/Projects/Diversity/Data/Report/report0727.pdf|journal=Brown University|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>. In addition to this systematic racial oppression, minority groups are further pushed down financially. As Glenn Ellis, a health advocacy communication specialist and author, said children that live in poverty have scary numbers to face: “25 percent more likely to drop out of school; 40 percent more likely to become a teen parent; 50 percent more likely to be placed in special education; 60 percent more likely never to attend college; 70 percent more likely to be arrested for a violent crime; and 30 percent of poor children score very low on early reading skills, compared to only 7 percent of children from moderate- or high-income families.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ellis|first=Glenn|date=December 2015|title=Sobering numbers on kids, poverty, race|url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1757017932?accountid=7418|journal=Philadelphia Tribune|volume=|pages=|via=ProQuest}}</ref>"
Critics of color-blindness{{Who|date=September 2017}} argue that color-blindness operates under the assumption that we are living in a world that is "[[post-race]]", where race no longer matters.<ref name ="Ansell 2006">{{cite journal | last = Ansell | first = Amy E. | title = Casting a blind eye: the ironic consequences of color-blindness in South Africa and the United States | journal = Critical Sociology | volume = 32 | issue = 2–3 | pages = 333–356 | publisher = [[Sage Publishing|Sage]] | date = March 2006 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/156916306777835349 | doi = 10.1163/156916306777835349 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
While the ideal that race should not "matter", critics{{Who|date=November 2017}} say, is certainly not a bad thing, the problem lies in asserting that race should not be taken into consideration even when trying to address inequality or remedy past wrongs.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Doane | first = Ashley | title = What is racism? Racial discourse and racial politics | journal = Critical Sociology | volume = 32 | issue = 2–3 | pages = 255–274 | publisher = [[Sage Publishing|Sage]] | date = March 2006 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/156916306777835303 | doi = 10.1163/156916306777835303 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
Abstract liberalism "abstracts and decontextualizes" themes from political and [[economic liberalism]], such as [[meritocracy]] and the [[free market]], to argue against the strong presence of racism.<ref>{{citation |last= Bonilla-Silva |first= Eduardo | contribution = "New racism," color-blind racism, and the future of whiteness in America | editor-last1 = Bonilla-Silva | editor-first1 = Eduardo | editor-last2 = Doane | editor-first2 = Ashley W. |title= White out: the continuing significance of racism |year= 2003 |publisher= Routledge |location= New York |isbn= 9780415935838 |pages= 271–284 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> It is also often used in discussions of affirmative action. The principle of laissez-faire emphasizes a "hands off" policy in terms of the government's involvement with economic activity. When applied to issues of race, it results in people being for equality in principle but against government action to implement equality, a policy often called [[laissez-faire racism]].
The "biologization of culture" explains the inequality among race today in terms of cultural difference. Where disparities were once explained in terms of biology, they are now being discussed in terms of culture. "Culture" in this framework is seen as something fixed and hard to change.<ref name ="Bonilla-Silva">{{citation | last= Bonilla-Silva | first= Eduardo | contribution = Color-blind racism: toward an analysis of white racial ideology | editor-last= Bonilla-Silva | editor-first= Eduardo |title=White Supremacy and Racism in the Post-Civil Rights Era |publisher=Lynne Rienner Publishers, Inc |year= 2001 | pages = 137–166 | isbn= 9781588260321 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> One example form of rhetoric used in this framework is the argument, "if Irish, [[Jew]]s (or other ethnic groups) have 'made it', how come blacks have not?"<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Bonilla-Silva | first1 = Eduardo | last2 = Lewis | first2 = Amanda | last3 = Embrick | first3 = David G. | title = I did not get that job because of a black man...!: the story lines and testimonies of color-blind racism | journal = Sociological Forum | volume = 19 | issue =4 | pages = 555–581 | date = December 2004 | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11206-004-0696-3 | ref = harv | postscript = .| doi = 10.1007/s11206-004-0696-3 }} doi:[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11206-004-0696-3 10.1007/s11206-004-0696-3].</ref> Such rhetoric blames blacks and other minority groups for their own situations because other previously disadvantaged groups have managed to 'make it' in American society.
Similarly, certain frameworks "naturalize" aspects of racism, used commonly in discussions of residential and school [[racial segregation|segregation]]. For example, using this framework one{{Who|date=November 2017}} would say it is simply natural that people of the same race would tend to live together, that it's "just the way it is". This viewpoint, however, critics{{Who|date=November 2017}} argue ignores the possibility of other factors underlying [[residential segregation]] such as the attitude of realtors, bankers, and sellers.<ref name ="Bonilla-Silva"/>
Finally, as color-blindness may rest on the idea that racism is no longer a prevalent issue today, a fourth framework seeks to minimize racism. Thus, modern occurrences of racism are seen as rare aberrations committed by the last few racists in society. Because racism is viewed as no longer a problem under this belief, people who ascribe to color-blindness see government programs targeting race as "illegitimate" and no longer necessary.
Robert D. Reason and Nancy J. Evans outline a similar description of color-blindness by Professor T.A. Forman of [[Emory University]], which is based on four beliefs: 1. racial groups receive merit-based privileges, 2. most people do not notice nor are they concerned about race, 3. social inequality today is due to "cultural deficits" of individual people or racial or ethnic groups, and 4. given the previous three assumptions, there is no need to pay "systematic attention" to any current inequities. They argue the prevalence of color-blindness is partially attributed to lack of knowledge or lack of exposure. Due to segregation that exists in housing and education, many Americans may not have direct contact with the discrimination that still exists.<ref name ="Reason">{{cite journal | last1 = Reason | first1 = Robert D. | first2 = Nancy J. | last2 = Evans | date = Winter 2007 | title = The complicated realities of whiteness: from color blind to racially cognizant | journal = New Directions for Student Services, special issue: Responding to the Realities of Race on Campus | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] | volume =2007 | issue = 120 | pages = 67–75 | doi = 10.1002/ss.258 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1002/ss.258 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
==Research== {{Refimprove science|section|date=September 2017}}
Fryer et al. showed that showed that color-blind affirmative action is about as efficient as race-conscious affirmative action in the short run, but is less profitable in the long term<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Fryer|first1=R. G.|last2=Loury|first2=G. C.|last3=Yuret|first3=T.|date=29 November 2007|title=An Economic Analysis of Color-Blind Affirmative Action|journal=[[Journal of Law, Economics, and Organization]]|volume=24|issue=2|pages=319–355|doi=10.1093/jleo/ewm053|authorlink1=Roland Fryer}}</ref>.
In 2010, Apfelbaum et al. exposed elementary school students to color-blind ideology and found that those students were less likely to detect or report instances of overt racial discrimination. The authors concluded "Color-blind messages may thus appear to function effectively on the surface even as they allow explicit forms of bias to persist."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Apfelbaum|first1=E. P.|last2=Pauker|first2=K.|last3=Sommers|first3=S. R.|last4=Ambady|first4=N.|title=In Blind Pursuit of Racial Equality?|journal=Psychological Science|date=28 September 2010|volume=21|issue=11|pages=1587–1592|doi=10.1177/0956797610384741}}</ref>
Amy Ansell, a sociologist at [[Bard College]], has compared and contrasted the development of the color-blindness in the United States and South Africa. Given that whites are a minority population in South Africa and a majority population in the United States, Ansell expected to see a significant difference in the manifestation of color-blindness in both countries. The thirty-year time difference between the departure from Jim Crow and cessation of [[apartheid]] and differences in racial stratification and levels of poverty also led Ansell to expect a clear difference between the colorblindness ideology in the United States and South Africa. However, she concludes that while color-blindness stems from two very different origins in the two countries, the current structure of color-blindness in the two countries is nearly identical.<ref name="Ansell 2006"/>
==Alternatives==
Researchers also offer alternatives to the color-blindness discourse. Reason and Evans call for people to become "racially cognizant", that is they need to acknowledge the role that race plays in their everyday lives. Being racially cognizant also demands a continuous examination and reinterpretation of race and how it affects our lives. It is also important to balance looking at a person as an individual and acknowledging the role their membership to a social group plays in their daily lives.<ref name="Reason"/>
Researcher Jennifer Simpson proposed that "in setting aside color blindness, Whites must learn to see, accept, and experience their lives as raced and to explore the possibility that some of the good, ease, or rewards they have experienced have not been solely the result of hard work and just effort but of a system biased in their favor." This conscious exploration of whiteness as a racial and social identity and the acknowledgment of the role of whiteness is connected to modern [[whiteness studies]].<ref name="Simpson">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1468-2885.2007.00317.x | last = Simpson | first = Jennifer Lyn | date = February 2008 | title = The color-blind double bind: whiteness and the (im)possibility of dialogue | journal = Communication Theory | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 139–159 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1468-2885.2007.00317.x | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> However, the field of [[whiteness studies]] has been criticized for its focus on reprimanding the white population, whereas similar fields such as Black studies, Women's studies, and Chicano Studies celebrate the contributions of the eponymous group.<ref>{{cite news | last1 = Fears | first1 = Darryl | title = Hue and cry on 'whiteness studies' | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A14386-2003Jun19 | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = 19 June 2003 | accessdate = 20 June 2003 }}</ref>
In a recent publication of the academic journal ''Communication Theory'', Jennifer Simpson proposed a "more productive dialogue about race". New dialogue must take a more complex look at race, openly looking at all different perspectives on race. As dialogue is a means of empowerment, it should take into account how all experiences contribute to our understanding, particularly those experiences very different from our own. Simpson believes that whites must be willing to openly engage with people of color in discussing the ongoing effects of racism today. However, this requires white people to participate in "communicative behavior that may threaten simultaneously their sense of self and their material power in the social order".<ref name="Simpson"/>
